snippet: Thousands of Iraqis have taken up residence among the poorly guarded ruins of Mesopotamia in illegally built homes, shops, greenhouses and garages, and they do not want to leave.
abstract: Mosul Journal; Thousands of Iraqis have taken up residence among the poorly guarded ruins of Mesopotamia in illegally built homes, shops, greenhouses and garages, and they do not want to leave; to Iraqi authorities, the residents are nothing more than illegal squatters who need to be moved; officials say they pose the latest threat to an archaeological patrimony that has been plundered by looters, pummeled by decades of war and disfigured by Saddam Hussein; they want to relocate the families and seal off the areas,

byline.contributor: Omar al-Jawoshy and an Iraqi employee of The New York Times contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of Iraqis have taken up residence among the poorly guarded ruins of Mesopotamia in illegally built homes, shops, greenhouses and garages, and they do not want to leave.

headline.seo: Mesopotamia Ruins at Risk From Iraqi Residents
headline.main: Seeking to Preserve the Past, but Stumbling on the Present
headline.print_headline: Seeking to Preserve the Past, but Stumbling on the Present
